Okay, so I'm trying to solve this genetics problem about guinea pigs. Let me read through it again carefully. The scenario is that a scientist crossed two guinea pigs, both with black coats. Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white).

Black hair is dominant over white, so we know that the dominant trait (black) is expressed, and the recessive trait (white) isn't visible in the presence of the dominant version. The offspring's traits are ¾ black and ¼ white. The question is asking about the genotypes of the parents, specifically which combination would result in these offspring ratios. Let me break down what I remember from Mendelian genetics. Since the coat color is determined by one gene, and it's a dominance situation, each parent contributes either the dominant or recessive allele for that gene. Given that all three-quarters of the offspring have black coats and one-quarter has white, that suggests a 3:1 ratio. In terms of probabilities, this could mean that each offspring has a 75% chance of having at least one dominant allele (black), and a 25% chance of having none (all recessives, white). So, if we're looking at dihybrid crosses or other combinations, how do the parents' genotypes look? The options given are A to J, but let me list them: A. Bb × Bb  
B. BB × BB and Bb × bb  
C. bb × Bb  
D. bb × bb  
E. bb × BB  
F. Bb × bb  
G. Bb × BB  
H. BB × Bb  
I. BB × bb  
J. BB × BB Wait, actually, looking back, the user provided the possible answers as G, H, I, J, etc., but perhaps some of my notes might be off. Let me think more clearly. The key here is figuring out the genotype of the parents that would produce such a ratio when crossed. Since the ratio is ¾ black to ¼ white, this implies that in each offspring, there must be at least one dominant allele (B) present because the recessive condition (bb) leads to white. If a parent were homozygous recessive (bb), then every offspring would inherit a b from both parents, resulting in bb and hence white coats. So any parent who is bb would cause all their offspring to have white coats. However, since the parents aren't all producing white, they can't both be bb. Therefore, at least one parent must be heterozygous (Bb), giving some chance of passing on the dominant allele. But wait, let me consider the possible parent combinations: Option D is bb × bb. If both parents are bb, all their offspring would get bb from each, leading to all white coats. That doesn't match the given data, so D is out. Similarly, E is bb × BB. The bb parent will always give b, while the BB parent gives B. So all offspring would be Bb, resulting in black coats. Again, no white coats, so E is not correct. Now, F is Bb × bb. The bb parent always gives b, while Bb can give either B or b. So half the offspring will be Bb (black) and half bb (white).

So half of the offspring would be Bb (black), and the other half bb (white). So the phenotypic ratio would indeed be 1:1, meaning 50% black and 50% white. But the problem states that three quarters have black, which would require a different outcome. Hmm, maybe I made a mistake earlier.

The probability would be 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. So phenotypically, BB and Bb are black (since B is dominant), and bb is white. That would give a 3:1 ratio—75% black, 25% white. Ah, okay, that makes sense now. So if both parents are Bb, each can produce four types of gametes: B, B, b, b, each at 25%. So the Punnett square would show 25% BB, 50% Bb, and 25% bb. Thus, three-quarters black and one-quarter white. That fits perfectly with the given ratio. So the parents must be Bb × Bb. Each parent can pass B or b. So 50% BB (from B and B), 50% Bb (from B and b). All of these would be black, so again, 100% black, which doesn't fit. Option J is BB × BB. Both parents are BB, so all offspring would be BB. Phenotype is all black. Doesn't fit. So the only option that works is when both parents are Bb, leading to a 3:1 ratio of black to white. Therefore, the correct answer should be D, which is bb × bb. Wait no, that's impossible because both parents can't be bb. Earlier analysis showed that if both parents are Bb, the offspring would be 75% black and 25% white, which matches the data. So the parents are Bb × Bb, which corresponds to option D.

The correct answer is D
